head.title: The Halls Are Alive With the Sound of Rest

hedline.hl1: The Halls Are Alive With the Sound of Rest

abstract.p: Letters from Bruce M Zelkovitz and Les Dreyer respond to May 30 article about Chris DeLaurenti, sound artist who secretly recorded intermission sounds emanating from orchestra pits and compiled CD of his greatest hits; drawing

block.p: ''The Concerts Found Onstage While Everyone Else Takes a Break'' (Arts pages, May 30):
''The Concerts Found Onstage While Everyone Else Takes a Break'' (Arts pages, May 30):
This fascinating article resonated with me, as I have practiced intermission sociology.
I attended the Metropolitan Opera and Glimmerglass Opera, enjoying myself and then taking intermission notes on people's conversations.

I hypothesized that people would focus on the performances. But I found that during opera intermissions, people most frequently talked about work, in particular work discontent. Family and friends came in a distant second, and the operas third.
For some comparative intermission research, I studied ice hockey games. The same pattern was discerned. And work was the thing.
It is indeed interesting to see what can be found ''in unexpected nooks.''
Bruce M. Zelkovitz Topeka, Kan., May 30, 2007

It's a pity that Chris DeLaurenti, the Seattle-based ''sound artist'' and composer, wasn't around in the early 1960s to clandestinely tape the intermission sounds emanating from the old Metropolitan Opera pit.

Preserved for posterity would be the anecdotal banter in French, German and Italian of musicians born in the 19th century; an incredible rendition of Paganini's ''God Save the Queen'' by my Italian stand-partner (on a violin presented to him by Benito Mussolini); the croaking of a contrabassoon reed, whittled by a former president of the Vienna Philharmonic; and my own youthful attempts to master a difficult passage of Strauss or Wagner.
The writer is a violinist with the Metropolitan Opera.
